posts.name: Jiovanni Zinedine Sookhai
posts.cooked: Hello, I’m a programmer with 2168, trying out auto alignment. I’ve made a previous post about this before, but I’ve been wondering what are your thoughts on these two types of alignment, and in your opinion, which one for your team is more reliable or effective? One approach relies on an accurate global pose estimate (vision + odometry or other means) to align to a preset, field-relative goal pose with left and right offsets. The other approach involves aligning to a single tag (or multiple, with one distinguished) that the camera is tracking and then creating offsets from that tag-relative pose. I’m considering these methods and am unsure which is more effective. Our current setup consists of three Limelights: two Limelight 3s mounted on the front and left side of the robot for pose estimation, and one Limelight 2, centered middle-low, serving as a single-tag tracker at preferably low distances.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
5987 had much better success when we switched from the first method to the second. We are still using a pose estimation (i.e. combination of camera and odometry data), but ignoring any tag that isn’t the one we are aligning with.

You can read more about how we’re doing auto-alignment on our Open Alliance thread:

FRC 5987 Galaxia | 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance FRC Open Alliance

5951 is technically doing the first method, but with cameras only pointed to the scoring side of the robot so when lined up to score the pose estimation is essentially only based on the current tag.

FRC 5951 Makers Assemble 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance 2025 FRC Open Alliance

AriMB:

5987 had much better success when we switched from the first method to the second

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
So, I agree with the the other posters that fusing apriltags with field odometry yields better results, but with one big caveat: It generally takes a good bit longer to program.

If you’re trying to do the fusion method I would definitely look at mechanical advantage and their vision template as a starting point. There are a lot of little lessons that go into that template.

If you’re just doing this for the first time and want to keep it simple, then using just the limelights is a lot easier to understand. You will still want to be careful about how it handles apriltags when you’re really close and really far away (both lead to different errors) But there is a post called zero to reef alignment (or something similar) on here that should get you 90% of the way there.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
4020 is using the global pose method and we’ve had excellent results (see, for example, Rocket City Finals 2 ).  I think what really matters is that you have accurately represented your camera-to-robot transformations and that your alignment algorithm is solid, whether it is of the global pose or local offset type.

One thing to keep in mind is that you are going to benefit from global pose for other tasks on the field including gross alignment to a reef face.  If you can’t get global pose good enough for fine branch alignment, you may still want to use it to get you close on the reef or for other purposes.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
paulonis:

One thing to keep in mind is that you are going to benefit from global pose for other tasks on the field including gross alignment to a reef face. If you can’t get global pose good enough for fine branch alignment, you may still want to use it to get you close on the reef or for other purposes.

This is our approach. Use the global pose to get to where we can see the reef tag and then position relative to just that tag. This insulates us from any potential deviations in the reef’s position or orientation w.r.t. the field. In our experience this was much less of an issue on the competition field than on the various fields we have practiced on.  But if another robot bumps and moves the reef during practice our autons don’t care.  This is pretty helpful.  It also means we are super flexible with our auton start positions (a good thing).
